name: Nuclear Throne
description: Nuclear Throne is a post-apocalyptic roguelike-like top-down shooter. Not 'the final hope of humanity' post-apocalyptic, but 'humanity is extinct and mutants and monsters now roam the world' post-apocalyptic. Fight your way through the wastelands with powerful weaponry, collecting radiation to mutate some new limbs and abilities.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP Processor: 1.2Ghz+ Memory: 1024 MB RAM Graphics: 256MB Storage: 200 MB available space Additional Notes: This game is locked to 30 frames per second.
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows XP Processor: 2Ghz Memory: 2048 MB RAM Graphics: 1GB Storage: 500 MB available space Additional Notes: This game is locked to 30 frames per second.

reviews.review_text: I bought this game when it was in its early access period(For 13 dollars multiplied by 4. Yes, my currency sucks) and I recently exprienced most of the content, meaning I can finally review it.   Nuclear Throne is a hard(and I mean HARD. at about 9 hours you'll be just getting used to the third area) roguelite top down shooter with a huge variety of weapons(above 140 I believe), a roster of 12(and a few secret) characters, 7 main areas(split into levels) with secret equivelants of most of them, and full of content.  Every session is quite short, and there is no end unless you choose to end the run.   Every enemy drops EXP upon death(rads), and when you level up you can choose 1 mutation(modifiers) out of a selection of 4 every time for 9 levels, and get a special choice on level 10. Mutations vary from trivial things such as faster move speed to kills reducing reload time.   The devs are extremley helpful and active on the forums(at least during the early acces period and until they finish updating the released product) and the community is the last one to be called a toxic community.    The game's lore was told partly through little references in-game, lore bits and pieces from twitch streams of the dev and more, and is worth a read on the wiki(Also run by a great guy). Nobody knows all of it(except for the developers), but what we do know is pretty damn good.   After defeating the first final boss, if you do a thing the community will eventually notify you about(or wiki), you will loop. Looping is going through the entire game all over again and will never end until you die/get either of the 2 endings. It includes new exclusive content and so much more. The loops are late game, and since they can last forever, the game has to become even more brutal with each loop, and on loop 1 already, without spoiling, you will notice a difficulty spike.     Pros   -Full of areas to explore, enemies to shoot and die to, weapons, synergies and more. -Will keep you playing for a good amount of time, but still is fit for short sessions if you're just passing time -Amazing and helpful community -Fantastic soundtrack(Personal favorites are Frozen City's B-Track(Ode on the official soundtrack) , and The Nuclear Throne) -Great pixel art that is just beautiful to look at.     Cons   -It takes a while for RNGesus to make some good weapons become common in the pool after the first time they drop -Sometimes the game would do flat out unfair actions, such a certain telefragging enemy -Inconsistent difficulty curve. Its smooth until the third boss, spikes, stays that way, lowers down a bit in the 7th area's boss and on loops spikes up again and goes through the same curve -Sometimes you just get screwed(even on spawn). RNGesus may not have mercy. -Some secrets that without a wiki/datamining no one would have found.  TLDR: NT is a great game to sink hours into, as well as to play in short sessions, is hard, but rewarding and fun, as well as full of content to exprience.

FRIENDLY REMINDER    something you must be aware of before buying   Nuclear Throne can be quite a stressful game that can lead you to have several rage moments so, if you can't really deal with this, I must say that this game is  NOT  for you and you should stay away from it. It's a very punishing game and small mistakes can lead you to death.   ABOUT    what is this game all about?   Nuclear Throne is an action shoot em' up roguelike game made by Vlambeer, where your objective is to reach the Nuclear Throne, your main enemy in the game.   STORY    does this game even have a story?   Some people might not know this, but this game actually has a background story. But, since this is not the main 'star of the show', it's okay for the game to have a lack of detailed storyline.    Humanity messed up with things and the world is nearly destroyed, although things still managed to live in such conditions. Along with creatures being mutated (and a human as well, this being Steroids), portals started to appear and those started teleporting mutants around the wasteland.  A mutant called 'Proto Mutant' discovered a place called The Palace, a place that is set to keep the world's balance, to keep it stable and we all know that's not the current case. Whenever a mutant stands up and gains strength enough to be able to do something against this mess that the world is, it gets sucked into a portal and disappear.  Other mutants heard about this myth and about the Nuclear Throne as well, which if destroyed, the world will get stabilized again, thus the game begins... .   There are some more details, but it could be considered a spoiler at some point. If you're interested in knowing more about it, you could simply check the game's Wikia and find out yourself.    GAMEPLAY    what do I do in this game?   Nuclear Throne is a game with a big focus on gameplay and it would be a shame if it weren't good, right? This game has playstyle similar to the well-known Binding of Isaac, but way faster. The controls are easy to understand and are really responsive. At first, it will be a little bit boring because of the lack of things happening, but as you progress through levels, things get better and way faster! Fun and challenging.  In a nutshell: You shoot things. Things die. Get weapon upgrades and new mutations to power yourself up. Progress to the next area. Repeat until you reach the Nuclear Throne.  The sad thing about this game is that it lacks an online Multiplayer, only a local Multiplayer option, which is not that bad, but since this game requires a lot of precision and quick responses, using a gamepad to play with someone else is a pain in the ♥♥♥, unless you manage to use two keyboards and two mices.   SOUNDTRACK & SOUNDS    how's the music and sound effects?   Vlambeer did an awesome job with the soundtrack the same way they did with  GUN GODZ  and their other games, the musics and songs fit really well. Boss battles, areas and everything else. And the mutants' voices and sound effects, like weapons and such are really well made as well.   GRAPHICS    wow, next gen. graphics plz!1!   You can probably tell that this game has pixelated graphics and, if you're a fan of super detailed and realistic graphics, this is not for you. The sprites in the game are well-made, the scenarios are great and suit each enemey very well. Also, their promotional art is awesome!   DIFFICULTY    how difficult is this anyway?   Okay, so, if there's a negative review out there, it probably is because of the difficulty and learning curve on this game. This is a really punishing game and little mistakes will make you get to the start of the game within a second, you must be cautious and think fast. As mentioned above, if you're a person that gets mad really fast or dislike games that are really difficult, you should probably avoid this.   REPLAY VALUE    how many hours can I put in this?   It's a 'short' game and you are going to die  A LOT , I assure you, if this game didn't have a great replay value, it would be absolute sh*t. If you enjoyed your first runs, you're probably going to enjoy the rest of it, since you're always progressing through the game, learning new things, trying out other mutants and mutations, yada, yada.   PERSONAL OPINION    what do you thinka 'bout the game after all?   More like a TL;DR, I guess. It's an awesome game with fast gameplay, charming graphics, responsive controls and incredible replay value, I highly recommend it if you're a big fan of the genre, and, since it finally released, there's no need for you to be hesitant about the early access part. Vlambeer will probably keep updating the game, so, there's much more content to come and much more to enjoy. Also, if you know and enjoyed the abovementioned Binding of Isaac and want to 'spice things up' and have a more 'breathtaking' experience, give this game a shot.  There are also some other aspects of this game that might be a turnoff to some people, such as: no widescreen option and 30 fps cap. Just wanted to point it out, since some dislike this.
It's one of those games. You can play it during coffee breaks, during work, during your life, before your death.

I suck hardcore at this game but I'm going to review it anyway (again). Basically it's a rouge-ish bullet hell game about a group of mutants who are on a journey to claim the nuclear throne, one of the most soul beating, ♥♥♥♥ kicking, rage inducing bosses ever (And it's not even really the final boss). You have a selection of 12 characters to play with, each with their strengths and weaknesses. It also includes a leveling up system with each level allowing you to choose from four powers, know as mutations. There are a multitude of stages with increasingly difficult enemies (But very few border the line of unfair). After a few levels a boss will spawn randomly from a wall or in the middle of the screen. These bosses range from: 'Pfft that was a boss?' to 'Ah ♥♥♥♥ I'm screwed, oh ♥♥♥♥ here he comes.' I'd say it is very skill based and unforgiving, so if you are into that kind of thing in a game this will be right up your alley. I still have yet to master it but I still find the fun in it even if I suck. Also the devs seem interested in just making games and constantly updated the game till its full release, and there will most likely be content later. There are a couple of drawbacks however. Due to the games random nature, you can get a reaaaaaaally bad spawn where the boss spawns two feet from you or where you have minimum protection against a huge wave of fish (no joke).    TL;DR Pros: A good selection of characters Good devs Fun yet not boringly easy Lots of secrets Nice art and sound tracks A looping system LOCAL Co-op  Cons:  A couple of unfair bosses/enemies RNG spawns can make you want to tear your arms off and slam your face on your keyboard Losing a great run can give you a heart attack Unsure post-EA future (Maybe) Flame Traps  Rating: 9.5/10

Part Rogue-like, Part RPG, part bullet-hell -- this game has a lot of charm and is quite addictive. Deceptively complex when you get down to the business of different levels and enemies and all the perks and weapon combinations you might use to prevail. I tried my darndest, but I could never win -- I'd gotten far, and I consider it a point of honor to win Rogue-likes that I love... but maybe someday I'll come back and try to beat it. In the meantime I had fun playing with multiple characters that actually play differently, and some great fun winning levels in crushing victory or by the skin of my teeth. Nuclear Throne, you have earned a place in my heart... a game that beat me, but I loved you anyway. <3

Be prepared to read the words 'You did not reach the nuclear throne' a lot. Be prepared to accidently kill yourself when your disk gun shot richocets off a wall and back at you. Be prepared for an adrenaline rush every time you face Lil' Hunter.  In this game, you will die a lot. It's bullet hell and you have 8 measly hit points. Seems like it's not a problem right? Well, most shots in the game will take down half that and more. There's no invincibility frames after getting hit, some enemies shoot powerful enough weapons that they will kill you in one shot.  And yet you keep playing.  There's a beautiful feel to the game. The gunfire sounds are audibly pleasing, Every hit on an enemy is satisfying. As you progress further, the game only gets more fun. After looping, you begin to feel unstoppable, but eventually you get claimed and the struggle continues. You always die in this game, but you die a little less frequently as you progress.  Do yourself a favor and pick this gem up. You won't regret it.  One small note, the developers have stopped working on the game, so if you see any bugs, it's unlikely you'll get a fix for it for a long time.

The dev team is devoted to making the game fun. This is superbly shown by the version of the game made for Ster_, plus the massive amount of content. And although I have not reached most of what the game has to offer because I am terrible at the game I know it is there and can not wait to get there. TL;DR This game stands as a light in the murky sea of Rouge-Likes.

I gave this game a negative review but now I recommend it because I've gotten all of the acvhievements ♥♥♥ u lmao gettouta 'ere.                                          Oh, uhm, expecting a serious review? Well, I wanted to leave this as a sh!tpost review, but it's just not in my nature. I'll still leave the first part so people can dislike without realising I wrote an actual review lol   SOOOooo... this game? What is this game? Well this game is an 'unfair' shoot 'em up with incredibly harsh rules. And I mean it, I don't over-exagerate here. No really, the game's hard. You got it? Do you still have casual blood? Nooo? Then let's continue.    The premise is simple: reach The Nuclear Throne. How wonderfully unsimple that sounds. And to reach the throne, you have to guide your little addorable mutant over from the campfire through a boundless onslaught carnage that awaits you ahead. Lovely.    And these mutants, oh, they are done very well and simple: everyone has a passive, an active ability, and a cool b-skin, which we'll mention in a tad bit. Since there are a total of 12 characters+2 secret ones, you can imagine there's a lot of diversity involved, each offering its own challenge, too. For an example: -You've got Crystal. She's unlocked from the start, has 2 extra passive hp(from 8 to 10) and the active ability to shield at will, which deflects projectiles and she's overall immune to damage while shielding. I say overall loosely. -And then you've got Melting. He's got straight up 2 hp and gains more rads(xp), and coming with his crippling health and depression is his active ability to blow up corpses. How is that useful? The explosions remove projectiles and damage enemies. Coming with his special mutation, all you're gonna hear late game is going to be pretty much BLAARGHBLERHG BALAAAARHG BLREHG etc. as you exit the level with no witnesses. So yeah, very well designed characters.    The gameplay itself is fast paced, the bullets are fast, some enemies are fast, but the most important thing that you have to remember is:  Everything. Is.  OVERPOWERED!   It's ranging from enemies, to damage, to your own damn weapons(looking at you, SPC). The best way to avoid the unavoidable death is to be good at dodging and never go head-on into danger. That includes your pick-ups, which btw enemies drop rads=xp and have a chance to drop ammo or health packs on their corpses. As much as I've played, few have been the runs that ended because of lack of ammunition, but it could happen if you just cannot aim for the life of you.    Speaking of xp, your mutants will level if you picked up enough rads, which grants mutations, and pretty a lot of them can change the course of your game, ranging from more health, homing bolts, and even a very special mutation that differs form one to another. As how much it is different I can say it is game changing for the most part, and I'll let you find out for yourself what does what ;) Another thing is that once you hit level ultra(10, that being), you gain the choice between two character-specific mutations, and all I can say is that they're awesome, since if I have to take each one apart, it'll cover the entire review.    Moving onto the levels, now THIS is where the RNG stands in. The layouts of all levels change drastically, from open space all the way to tiny ity-bitty corridors. I won't even mention the spawns, those awaken the PTSD in me. Each particular level has its own enemies, which again, they're so many, it'll take a long time, but I can say that for the most part of weapons in the game, there is an enemy that does the exact same thing. Close enough, anyway. Once you have defeated the  final boss , you are given the option to  loop  the game, which means you are put all the way to zone 1, all mutations, current weapons, and all enemies are stronger and cluster-♥♥♥♥ed at once. As you can imagine, the best way to put this is 'good luck'.    The crowns. At some point in the game you will encounter a statue, it collects rads, spawns a portal and you get yourself a cool crown. Awesome, yes? Right? For the most part, the crowns are a tad bit underwhelming, and for the most part they're not even helpful. With the exception of Crown of Blood, of course. Esentially, they have to give you an upside and a downside, which it's called a trait, btw. Some of the downsides however are excruciating: no health drops, no ammo drops, SPAWN AT ONE HEALTH EACH LEVEL. As much as the devs tried their best to make the crowns useful, I still think all of them are a myth, as the only true crown is Crown of Blood.    Oh yes, almost forgot the B-skins mentioned earlier. The crowns and these skins are the supposed challenges of the game. In order for each crown to be unlocked on a character you have to loop with it, and now for each B-skin it has got its own requeiremens. The unlock process ranges from easy to tedious in a blitz. It can have you go to a secret level on the second stage all the way to beating the third boss on a loop. In the end, we can all agree the skins are looking slick and much more handsome than your starting character. So I'd say are worth it.   tl;dr To be frank with you I have mixed feelings about this game. Not about love and hate, mind you, but more like, for how much it has been in early access, it could have been greater than this. But for what it is, it's a good masochistic game to kill some time on. Most of the runs from start to finish are usually 15 minutes, the unmentioned soundtrack in the review is quite beautiful to listen to, and overall this is the best adrenaline rush I've played in my life. I'm sure in the upcoming years, one student will beat this master, but for how it is now, it's the best one of its kind out there. The grade I'm willing to give to this game is an 8/10. Definetly recommend. This has been your random reviewer, signing off. Peace!

So, Nuclear Throne. This game will make you question how good you are, how fast your reflexes need to be, how quickly you can kill an enemy before they end up ending you. 100 hours of Binding of Isaac? Doesn't matter in the slightest.  Cons: ~Will make you hate yourself ~Will take time to master ~Will make you rage ~Will make you die  Pros: ~Erase all cons ~Make you love yourself ~Feels hefty, weighty, satisfying ;) ~You will get better ~FREEPLAY (Looping)  Some final advice I can give: Don't beat yourself up about dying hundreds of times to finally get to the Nuclear Throne, and then die to it. Ultra mutations are satisfying as hell to reach, and if you get past the Nuclear Throne you can loop, which some players might find upsetting as you no longer have a goal, and you will eventually die. However I can't stress enough how fun trying your build out on waves of enemies really is. I find that if I can get to that point, any way I die will just be funny, and I'll restart the game and go for it again. It may not feel like you're getting better, or know how to get better, but you definitely will after enough hours.  All In All: Definitely recommend it, if you want to get better or want to see someone skilled play, check out SLEEPCYCLES (Big Tam) or Chubbyemu (I haven't seen much of his stuff though) on youtube.

Like Luftrausers, Nuclear Throne is a basically competent and slick-looking shooter that turns out to be a lightweight when you look past the retro-chic veneer. Of my six hours with the game four were spent stuck on the same boss. Of course, this wouldn't be a problem if reaching the said boss was fun. It isn't.  Neither the overly simple level generation system or the enemy design add any variety to the inevitable retries, and unlike in certain other similar games, the bosses and enemy types stay the same every time you play. Since you have to completely clear out each level before continuing, there's no way to play dangerously to get more equipment or other advantages, which eliminates the risk-reward strategizing that's at the heart of pretty much every successful roguelike ever made. Thanks to this the majority of the game becomes a joyless slog towards whatever point you're currently stuck at.

The game's idea of a 'challenge' is to spawn you in the middle of 50 enemies. There is absolutely no control over what the game decides to throw your way, sometimes you get ridiculously easy levels, sometimes literally impossible ones. The game is fine for the first round, but after you 'loop' the game it drops the ball completely.  Having spent over 100 hours in this game, all I can say is last 50 hours of that I was ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off trying to endure the bs the game throws at you. If you do get the game, don't bother with the looping, it's a waste of your time. There's also an entire game mechanic (crowns) dedicated to making the game even harder than it is, which I'm sure the 0.001% of the playerbase who find the game too easy will appreciate greatly.  A similar game that does everything better is Enter the Gungeon. Both are very hard games, but in Gungeon the difficulty is fair and you can learn to overcome whatever it throws at you. In Nuclear Throne random stuff happens and you die.

So, this game. What about this game?  How about the fact that it's EXTREMLY difficult.  So when you start playing, you'll realize that the bandit does 3 damage, thats 1/3 of your health, already gone. The first enemy you see, does enough damage to KILL you in 3 hits. Don't even get me started with the scorpions. They fll the screen with a TON of green projectiles that are nearly unavoidable.  Nothing wrong with the sewers, so what about the scrapyard? Tons of birds that shoot 3 bursts of bullets, and guess what? Each bullet does 3 damage; enough to kill you. Also, you have sniper robots that sit at the back of the map and shoot 3 high-velocity bullets, and guess what? Each bullet does 3 damage; enough to kill you.  See where I'm going with this?  Next is the crystal caves, an area filled with fast crystal spiders that can easily kill you because they're so hard to hit, and they can gang up on you.  And then, the frozen city. Guess what? A robot yeti that dashes across the screen, which can easily take you out if you could'nt notice him over the sound of the robot dogs shooting 3 bullets when it rolls, and guess what? Each bullet does 3 damage; enough to kill you. And to make it worse, each stage in this city is filled with tanks that fire a barrage of bullets.  Then, the labs, a place full of mutants that can easily overwhelm you, as well as a necromancer that can revive up to 6 more mutants. Worse than that, there are sort of kamikazi mutants that run up to you and explode, easily taking you down as you're getting mauled by the swarm of mutants.  And then, the palace. Ooohhh god. This must be Satan's castle, because it is FILLED with enemies that fill the screen worse than a golden scorpion can.  I can't explain anything about the Throne, because guess what? I never reached it.  I wonder why?

So after playing this game for about an hour and a half, I really struggle to find anything negative to say. The game is a birds eye run and gun bullet hell type of shooter with roguelike elements including permadeath, leveling, and randomly generated areas. Now the graphics here are simple, and the music may become a bit repetitive after dying a bunch, but wholistically the audiovisual presentation is fantastic. Everything has punch and pizzaz. While the character designs I've seen so far arent really anything unusual, besides maybe the crystal golem character, they all have a lot of charm. The gameplay is fast, energetic, and challenging. There is no wasted time between the action either. The longest downtime youll see is when you mull over switching a weapon or which perk to take when you level up. When you kill the final enemy in an area, you get sucked directly into the next level, no meandering about. Bosses show up a little unexpectedly and depending on the number of supporting enemies around can be quite the death knell. Weapons are spaced fairly evenly and ammo and health arent exceedingly common. These and experience can be picked up with a fair amount of magnetism, but what is really clever about all these (besides the weapons) is that they disappear in only a few seconds, which encourages you to move into areas where you risk taking damage. Vlambeer doesnt want you to be too cool and calculated. The game can be a bit ambiguous with the perk descriptions, and you have no real way of knowing how a weapon compares to what you already have without trying it out. For the energy weapons particularily, I had no idea what to expect. You can only carry two, so you have to choose carefully. Whether these things are positive or negative is up to your perspective, this sort of try it and see what you get attitude is common to roguelikes. Ultimately I found the game to be extremely fun and well worth its farily low price point.

Nuclear Throne is quite possibly one of the best videos games I have ever played, if not the best. Here I will attempt to explain everything that makes this game so close to perfect.  -GAMEPLAY The controls are tight, and incredibly satisfying. Every weapon feels extremely fun to use, even if it is something ♥♥♥♥♥♥ like the Flare Gun. Each of the 12 main characters have their own Pros and Cons, yet none of the are bad or OP, some are just easier or harder to use. All of the enemies are challenging, but with practice you can learn how to properly defeat them. The games is incredibly fast-paced, and later on can get a little bit hectic. Even after 200+ hours, I still have things to learn.  GRAPHICS AND SOUND The game does use the standard for indie games it seems, being pixel art, but the art is really well made. Every sprite has so much detail put into it! From bandits to monsters made of radiation, each sprite is unique and looks amazing. The soundtrack is also absolutley perfect, with each track fitting every area and boss. The soundtrack is definetly the best one I've ever heard in a video game.  In conclusion, you should absolutlely buy this game. It is extremley challenging, but also extremley fun, with endless replayability and many secrets. BUY THIS STUFF DUDE!

Nuclear Throne is an awesome game. It's fun, has a lot of content to unlock and is very challenging. Almost everything about this game is solid, from the fast paced combat to the many enemies and guns. So there’s no reason for me to waste your time going into depth about everything awesome about this game. Throw your money at Vlambeer and play this game! So I’ll go over the bad parts of the game, it’s lack of character and mutation variety.  The game has twelve different character to play with, each with their own abilities and perks. But your playstyle doesn’t usually change from character to character. You'll find yourself taking the same mutations and the same guns, so your playthrough's might not differ to much from one another. Two characters are an exception to this, Melting and Rouge. Playing as them changes which perks you take and how the game operates, making playing with these two characters a unique experience from the rest of the game. While the other characters are unique and well designed, you’ll fight enemies in more or less the same way, take the same guns and take the same mutations. The mutations (or perks) in this game are cool, but have a clear order in how you take them. Some mutations are always better than others.  This lack of variety is the game’s main downfall in my eyes, but it’ll still keep you playing for a long time and is one of my favorite rouge-likes out there. Despite all I’ve said, I give this a 9/10. :D

Vlambeer (The dev) Has for some reason decided to put black bars on the top and bottom and 'sideart' on the sides of the screen restricting the actual game to only around 80% What it should be.Leaving you open to being shot by extremely high velocity shots from offscreen with no warning killing you almost always  The portal is also a big issue because it can turn a great run bad instantly by sucking you in and even sometimes killing you by blowing up explosives around it therefore not allowing you to get ammo and other important things.Almost always in my experience dooming you to a quick death by spawning you in front of all the enemies with no cover anywhere allowing them to gun you down easily like a firing squad.  I still haven't even gotten to the end let alone beat it.  of course I do have to admit I play with a 60 Hz monitor which is definitely not recommended But still not the cause of any of what I have described here.  Ultimately this has been one of the most frustrating and disheartening experiences I've ever had the displeasure of experiencing and I do not recommend buying it.

I have played a multitude of rogue likes, bullet hells, and overall difficult games so much that i know exactly what a good rogue like and/or bullet hell is supposed to be like and in all honesty Nuclear Throne has THE POTENTIAL to be among the greats. Now don't get me wrong there is a lot to love about this game the enemies, the lore which although isn't too obvious is still pretty easy to pick up on whether it just be from clues in the game or what HAS been confirmed, the mutlitudes of guns, power ups A.K.A. Mutations, and of course characters with their own unique styles of gameplay. With all of this being said though i feel i have to address the main issue of this game before i simplify it with a pros and cons list now like many of the players of this game i've been around since it first popped up on steam in early access and have been with it all the way. As the why that is important is because i've seen this game have it's problems, it's bugs, it's glitches, and it's crashes as well as seen drastic changes in some characters the main one being chicken due to her complete change in special power so in short i've seen how bumpy the road to where the game is now was and am happy to see the result.  But unfortunately even with this game out of early access i feel as though it should be made clear that the game developers in truth stopped caring about this game's fine polishing. Don't get me wrong for me i haven't encountered any bugs or major issues with the game on a very technical level but i have encountered several issues with certain gameplay aspects as well as functions within the game. The main issues shall be listed below so that you can read them each individually.  -The first final boss of the game 'The Throne' is by far more difficult than it's second stage upon looping as well as the absolute FINAL boss of the game to end any loop run the I.D.P.D. Captain. This issue comes from the fact that even with a hell fire of bullets being shot at you as well as many other forms of attack the throne 2 and the I.D.P.D. captain have a basic pattern which although becomes more challenging as the fight goes on is still a pattern that can be followed whilst the throne isn't like this at all. Instead of having just a set pattern it eventually get's to a point where there are so many bullets being shot at you that unless you have the jack hammer, Euphoria, Eyes' throne butt, or are playing crystal the chances of your success without having an incredibly powerful weapon in your arsenal are basically non existant.  -Enemy spawn points are possibly the NUMBER ONE priority of any RNG based game such as this especially when unlike other RNG based games this one drops you smack dab into the neck area instead of you walking through a door or what not. With this being said i'm not saying by any means they should put you in a protective cage then you leave when you feel like it but i have had a multitude of very good runs ended because i was placed in unwinnable scenarios. A prime and recent example of this is when i was play with melting who if you are not aware is the weakest character now i had strong spirit which prevents deathe once per level, rhino skin, boiling veins, euphoria, and hammerhead so i thought i would be fine. However upon being sent to the first part of the palace on a no loop run i had at least ten or so I.D.P.D. units spawn right on top of me now this wouldn't have been that bad had it been just grunts but the first three leading the charge were the shielding units so even if i did shoot my bullets would have come back to me and killed me anyways.  Now you might be thinking 'Oh well if you had a melee weapon you could have just deflected the bullets!' and that is true if i DID have a melee weapon i would've possibly been able to do something but because this is an RNG game where the weapon drops are random the only melee weapon i encountered in that run up until that point was the screwdriver and it's energy counterpart and even if i had take it let's be honest it would have done nothing so overall it was a good run ended by ridiculous means.  -Enemy Difficulty/Damage output now in regards to this issue it just feels like to me they're trying to establish mini bosses but incorporating them as regular enemies and that in truth is by far a terrible decision. First let me address the Assassin type enemy which is a purple bandit that wields a melee weapon and will pretend to be dead until you get close to it or something else occurs. Basically my main issue with this enemy in particular is just that it has too much going for it in it's favor yes it is in fact a weak enemy and is very easy to kill IF mind you you can hit it or even see it coming. You see the fact of the matter is they incorporated a somewhat stealth enemy which before looping is fairly easy to spot and yes i know when you loop it is meant to be harder but between dodging bullets, keeping track of nearly every enemy on the screen, and just overal avoiding death the fact that the assassin has such a high damage output, is fairly hard to hit with most weapon types, and can just easily sneak up on you in a hell storm of death is just not good design.  After the Assassin though the only other enemy in the game that isn't balanced is the Radiation dogs. Now forgive me if that isn't their proper name but they are a four legged creature you can solely encounter in the place before looping and much like the assassin they have too much going for them. I have had runs where i had scarier face, laser brains, and even if my weapon in question was not an energy weapon such as the hyper slugger or even the super slugger combo'd with scarier face seems to do almost nothing to them. In fact most of the time i find myself losing nearly have my ammunitions due to how tough this enemy is even with a mutation specifically meant to make things easier to kill.  Not only that but the when you combo their durability with how much distance they can cover in a single leap if you are put into a bad spawn or are forced into a corner by more than one you might as well just let go of the mouse and keys (or controller) and wait for death to occur.  -Damage inconsistencies are possibly the saddest thing i can't believe they've let slide for many a time i will have so much as five or six health and one bullet will take me down to either one or kill me out right. Now don't think i'm addressing ALL bullets such as the large orbs fired by the crown guardians and the throne i'm talking about the noraml type of bullet you most commonly see. Not only that but i've also at many points found that even whilst behind cover i suddenly die from an enemy who i clearly saw shot the cover but it somehow still connect with me which shouldn't even be there.  Now for the simplified Pros/Cons  Pros -----  -Original  -Good character variation  -Immense weapon variety  -Very challenging yet rewarding gameplay  -Unique connections to the characters and the world around them  -Multitude of ways the game can be altered A.K.A. the crown system  -Can basically be endless  -Lots of areas  -Bosses and Weapons that can only be accessed via looping  -Alternate versions of characters to unlock  -Alternate Starting weapons A.K.A. Golden Weapons  -Lots of fun and unique secrets  Cons ------  -Inconsistencies with enemy damage output  -Unwinnable spawns and/or enemy generation  -The first 'final' boss of the game is more challenging than those that come after it  -Certain enemies are too powerful  -Projectiles and other forms of damage can at rare moments afflict you when they shouldn't  Overall this IS a good game a fun one and a very cherished one to me as a lover of this genre of games however it feels as though the developers aren't really trying and they much like many others are substuting actual diffculty with just surplus.

I have more hours logged on this game than on all the others in my library combined, and I know I paid less for it than most. Don't miss this one! Compared to most other games, the mechanics are simple, but this game gives you a lot of leeway when it comes to playstyles. In my opinion, this is the formula for a great game. Look at minecraft, released seven years ago, it still has a HUGE playerbase! Creativity is encouraged in a world with simple rules and bright colors. Now, this game is a lot harder than Minecraft; you'll die a lot. That said, I've never been noticably frustrated by dying in this game. The game can go on forever if you know how, so dying is almost always the way I conclude my runs. The game is also very attractive through it's punchy audio and bright, fast graphics. Nuclear Throne is almost as fun to watch as it is to play.
I keep wanting to play this game even though its really hard. Really fun, especially with a friend, but just incredibly hard also.

This game is tons of fun; everytime i sit down to play for an hour, i wind up playing for three. ^_^  The action is quick, the guns are balanced well, and the characters are interesting and varied. You can run through the whole game in 20 minutes, but you almost never will. It is brutally difficult, and you are constantly on the verge of death, but the game is fast paced enough that death is never a setback. It plays, sort of, like a simple and quick diablo clone with guns and explosions, but without the tedious equipment management.  The game promotes itself as being 'roguelike' but, frankly, i dont think the comparison is accurate. It has procedurally generated levels, yes, but it takes alot more than that to fulfill the criteria, if you ask me. Still, whatever you want to call it, it scratches that itch, and a few others.  Very much worth the cost, i would pay twice as much as this, and i absolutely recommend it. DONT PASS IT UP!! :D

Pros: -Easy-to-grasp controls and mechanics -Throne-Buttloads of weapons -Every character is unique in their own way -Tons of post-loop content -Music is simple but fitting; doesn't overstate what is actually happening -Addition of Dailies and Weeklies allows for at least semi-regular fresh play  Neutrals/Subjective: -Difficulty curve can seem kinda ridiculous to newer players -Most weapons become less useful late-game, so the amount of 'useful' weapons is almost certainly less than the full list -Not every character is 'as good' as the others -Balance in general may seem kinda wonky to some -Art style may not appeal to everyone -Much of the 'post-loop' content is mostly just unlocking golden weapons, crowns, B-skins, and getting to as high of a loop as possible -While randomly generated, levels have similar elements and patterns that can make things feel samey.  Cons: -Seems that the console versions (and some people's PC versions from what I've heard) are fairly buggy, and patches aren't all too frequent. If you find bugs, you may have to deal with until it becomes a big enough problem that Vlambeer fixes it next patch -No 'native' modding support for current version (This is because of the version of GameMaker it runs in, which at this stage is not decompilable). You'll have to revert back to beta 19 to mod. -Controller controls, while definitely playable, are definitely not as good as keyboard/mouse (this falls a little on the subjective side, though)

The perfect game when you feel you're up for a challenge. You can complete a run in less than 15-20 minutes. Nuclear Throne has a lot of unpredictability due to level maps being procedurally-generated, varying enemy numbers, random power-ups and a huge amount of weapons. Gameplay can sometimes require very abrupt changes in pace. For example, you are forced to be patient, if the currently-generated level has a chokepoint somewhere and a lot of enemies after it. If you rush, you're as good as dead. On the other hand, there are a few enemy types that can spawn other enemies and if you don't kill them as soon as possible, you will either be overwhelmed or you'll run out of ammo.  The music gives a western vibe and helps immersion, but you shouldn't get too sure of yourself - after acing several levels, you can very quickly find yourself barely alive on the next. There are places where you can hardly see where you're going and you never know what's behind the next corner. The perfect illustration of how harsh the environment can be and that everything is out to get you is that even the ammo chests bite sometimes. It must be a coincidence that it usually happens when you barely have any HP left.

So much to unlock, every game is unique, FUN AS HELL, intensly difficult, IT'S A GREAT WAY TO PASS TIME, neverending fun, unique and fun characters, cool lore, hundreds of hours of gameplay... There's hundreds of reasons I'd recommend this game, and I can only think of one thing that I don't like too much about it: and that's that the story isn't really told to you in the game, and there are some completely random and overly specific ways to unlock certain characters, both of which require you looking up online. However, there is a great online NT wiki that explains everything for you, which as long as you have an internet connection, fixes this one con.  Basically, it's a damn good game. Get it

I love Rogue like games. They are some of the most intense, engaging, and high-tension action games there are. Unfortunately good ones can be hard to come by. I was at first turned away by the strange setup and cartoonish characters, however I quickly grew past it as I began to play. I have played many rogue-likes such as Risk of Rain, Enter the Gungeon, and Realm of the Mad God. This game is by far the best rogue like I have ever played, with its amazing replayability, multitude of weapons that make you feel like a badass and cool character abilites. Each character gives a new ability that augments the base playstyle quite nicely. They do not drastically affect the gameplay but change it just enough to be interesting and fresh. Additionally, if you are looking for a big change in the game, or greatly increased difficulty, never fear, for there are many different modes for that. In conclusion if you are a fan of Rogue-likes, this game is a MUST HAVE. On the other hand if you have never tried Rogue-Like's then this is the perfect game to get started with.

This game is a masterpiece. Utilising an intelligent levelling system and perk layout, Nuclear Throne never feels like a waste of time.  The gunplay is superb and you never feel overpowered or at adisadvantage, while still allowing for both frightening battles of survival and massacres of triumph. The variety of weapons also allows for different encounters, forcing player to adapt to the firearms available.  Each character's passive and active skill fit differently into the game, immediately refreshing stages and putting a new spin on a run. While no character is outright stronger than another, their abilities allow them each to dominate a certain situation.  The implementations of Mutations, which allow players to choose from a set of four perks after they level up, allows players to continue having a chance against stronger and stronger foes. Proper choice of Mutations is important, since you only get a certain amount.  Overall, I feel as though I have only begun to scratch the surface of the game, and feel that there are many more hours of enjoyment waiting. This game is a gem, and I would buy it again in a heartbeat. It even has co-op!
